_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Add bleeder valve on E-1556 shell side
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Deisobutanizer
Basic Process Description
This unit processes all of the LPG that is produced in the refinery.  Through the process of distillation, pentane (gasoline) and normal butane are removed from the rest of the LPG.  The normal butane and Pentane are blended into gasoline, the Butane to improve the cold starting ability of engines.  The DIB also produces some fuel gas that is sent to the refinery fuel gas system.  The rest of the LPG is sent to the LPG Unit for further separation.

Inspections
All process units were involved in a major plant turnaround in April/May 2009. This is a time in which normally operating processes are shut down for maintenance and inspections (except the tank farm). Several process vessels were inspected during a two-week period the date of May 1st was used as the date of last inspection.

Ongoing management 
The ongoing management of refinery process hazards requires the regular implementation of many PSM/RMP prevention elements.  Changes regularly occur in refinery processes, which require modifications to the process safety information, implementation of the management of change procedure, and require a pre-startup safety review.  Incident Reports are written regularly to document and investigate incidents that resulted in; property damage, environmental contamination, vehicle accidents, and injuries including first aid or incidents that may have resulted in something occurring (such as process upsets).  Incident Reports are considered a key component in our overall prevention program as we focus on learning from small incidents before they become significant.

As part of this 2009 update, Tesoro recalculated process volumes for each unit using detailed engineering calculations. This was done because we also used these detailed quantities in a facility siting assessment and the RBMI (Risk Based Mechanical Integrity) program.  The calculated volume for this process unit changed from 115,058 lbs.to 95,500 lbs.

_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: V-512 isolation (OOS, Out Of Service) dead leg removal
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Amine Unit

Basic Process Description                                                                 The Amine Unit uses a special solvent called amine to absorb hydrogen sulfide out of the LPG and fuel gases that are produced in the Crude Unit, Vacuum Unit, Hydrocracker and Reformer.  The absorption is accomplished in special scrubbing towers located at the southwest corner of the Hydrocracker.  The scrubbed LPG is sent to the DIB Unit for further processing.  The scrubbed fuel gas is piped to the refinery fuel gas system where it is burned in the process heaters and boilers.  The Hydrogen sulfide rich amine is sent to the Amine Regeneration section of the process.  In this section, the hydrogen sulfide is stripped out of the amine and sent to the Sulfur Recovery Unit.  The regenerated amine is cooled and circulated back to through the scrubbers.

Inspections
All process units (including the Amine) were involved in a major plant turnaround in April / May 2009. This is a time in which normally operating processes are shut down for maintenance and inspections (except the tank farm).  Because many process vessels were inspected during a three-week period the date of May 1st was used as the date of last inspection.

Ongoing management 
The ongoing management of refinery process hazards requires the regular implementation of many PSM/RMP prevention elements.  Changes regularly occur in refinery processes, which require modifications to the process safety information, implementation of the management of change procedure, and require a pre-startup safety review.  Incident Reports are written regularly to document and investigate incidents that resulted in; property damage, environmental contamination, vehicle accidents, and injuries including first aid or incidents that may have resulted in something occurring (such as process upsets).  Incident Reports are considered a key component in our overall prevention program as we focus on learning from small incidents before they become significant.

As part of this 2009 update, Tesoro recalculated process volumes for each unit using detailed engineering calculations. This was done because we also used these detailed quantities in a facility siting assessment and the RBMI (Risk Based Mechanical Integrity) program. The calculated volume for this process unit changed from 44,600 lbs. to 57,500 lbs.

_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Added SIF (Safety Instr Functions) testing ability
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Crude Unit
Basic Process Description
     The Crude Unit is the first process in converting crude oil into petroleum products.  This unit takes the oil and heats it to approx. 700 degrees F. and injects it into a tower where, through distillation, products such as diesel and jet fuel are produced.  Also distilled out of the crude oil is a heavier oil called gas oil, which is sent to the Hydrocracker for further processing.

Naphtha and light straight run gasoline are produced as feedstocks for the Reformer and PRIP Units.

LPG, or liquefied petroleum gas, is also distilled out of the crude oil.  This is processed in the Amine Unit to remove hydrogen sulfide from it and then sent on to the DIB and LPG units, which separates the LPG into propane and butane.

Petroleum gases that are produced from the crude oil are sent to the Amine Unit for hydrogen sulfide removal and then used as fuel gas for the refinery heaters and boilers.

After distilling all of these products from the crude oil, the residue is removed from the bottom of the distillation tower and sent to the Vacuum Unit for further processing.

Inspections
All process units (including the crude unit) were involved in a major plant turnaround in April / May 2009. This is a time in which normally operating processes are shut down for maintenance and inspections (except the tank farm).  Because many of the process vessels were inspected during a two-week period the date of May 1st was used as the date of last inspection.

Ongoing management 
The ongoing management of refinery process hazards requires the regular implementation of many PSM/RMP prevention elements.  Changes regularly occur in refinery processes, which require modifications to the process safety information, implementation of the management of change procedure, and require a pre-startup safety review.  Incident Reports are written regularly to document and investigate incidents that resulted in; property damage, environmental contamination, vehicle accidents, and injuries including first aid or incidents that may have resulted in something occurring (such as process upsets).  Incident Reports are considered a key component in our overall prevention program as we focus on learning from small incidents before they become significant.

As part of this 2009 update, Tesoro recalculated process volumes for each unit using detailed engineering calculations. This was done because we also used these detailed quantities in a facility siting assessment and the RBMI (Risk Based Mechanical Integrity)program. The calculated volume for this process unit changed from 722,152 lbs. to 846,878lbs.

_prev_prog_3.Description:
Reformer
Basic Process Description
       The Reformer takes naphtha produced in the Crude Unit and Hydrocracker and, using a catalyst, converts it into a high-octane gasoline component called reformate.  The unit also produces hydrogen and LPG as by-products.  The hydrogen is piped to the Hydrocracker and Hydrogen Unit; the LPG is sent to the DIB and LPG Units for separation into propane and butane.

Inspections
All process units (including the reformer) were involved in a major plant turnaround in April/May 2009. This is a time in which normally operating processes are shut down for maintenance and inspections (except the tank farm).  Several process vessels were inspected in the Reformer during a two-week period, the date of May 1st was used as the date of last inspection.

Ongoing management 
The ongoing management of refinery process hazards requires the regular implementation of many PSM/RMP prevention elements.  Changes regularly occur in refinery processes, which require modifications to the process safety information, implementation of the management of change procedure, and require a pre-startup safety review.  Incident Reports are written regularly to document and investigate incidents that resulted in; property damage, environmental contamination, vehicle accidents, and injuries including first aid or incidents that may have resulted in something occurring (such as process upsets).  Incident Reports are considered a key component in our overall prevention program as we focus on learning from small incidents before they become significant.

As part of this 2009 update, Tesoro recalculated process volumes for each unit using detailed engineering calculations. This was done because we also used these detailed quantities in a facility siting assessment and the RBMI (Risk Based Mechanical Integrity) program.  The calculated volume for this process unit changed from 99,948 lbs. to 293,510 lbs.

_prev_prog_3.Description:
(LPG) Liquefied Petroleum Gas Unit
Basic Process Description
      The LPG unit separates the remaining fuel gas from the LPG that has been processed in the DIB Unit.  It then takes the LPG and separates it into Propane and Iso-butane.  The propane is sold as bottle gas.  The Iso-butane is vaporized and used as fuel gas.

Inspections
All process units (including the LPG unit) were involved in a major plant turnaround in April/May 2009. This is a time in which normally operating processes are shut down for maintenance and inspections (except the tank farm).  Several process vessels were inspected during a two-week period the date of May 1st was used as the date of last inspection.

Ongoing management

Incident Reports are written regularly to document and investigate incidents that resulted in; property damage, environmental contamination, vehicle accidents, and injuries including first aid or incidents that may have resulted in something occurring (such as process upsets).  Incident Reports are considered a key component in our overall prevention program as we focus on learning from small incidents before they become significant.

As part of this 2009 update, Tesoro recalculated process volumes for each unit using detailed engineering calculations. This was done because we also used these detailed quantities in a facility siting assessment and the RBMI (Risk Based Mechanical Integrity) program.  The calculated volume for this process unit changed from 26,741 lbs. to 41,000 lbs.

_prev_prog_3.Description:
Partial Recycle Isomerization Process (P.R.I.P.)
Basic Process Description
This process takes the light straight run gasoline produced in the Crude Unit and, through a reaction process, converts into a higher-octane gasoline component called isomerate.   Hydrogen from the Hydrogen Unit is used in this process.  A small amount of LPG is also produced as a by-product.

Inspections
All process units (including the PRIP unit) were involved in a major plant turnaround in May 2003. This is a time in which normally operating processes are shut down for maintenance and inspections (except the tank farm).  Because all process vessels were inspected during a two-week period the date of May 15th was used as the date of last inspection.

Ongoing management 
The ongoing management of refinery process hazards requires the regular implementation of many PSM/RMP prevention elements.  Changes regularly occur in refinery processes, which requires modifications to the process safety information, implementation of the management of change procedure, and require a pre-startup safety review.  Incident Reports are written regularly to document and investigate incidents that resulted in; property damage, environmental contamination, vehicle accidents, and injuries including first aid or incidents that may have resulted in something occurring (such as process upsets).  Incident Reports are considered a key component in our overall prevention program as we focus on learning from small incidents before they become significant.

As part of this 2009 update, Tesoro recalculated process volumes for each unit using detailed engineering calculations. This was done because we also used these detailed quantities in a facility siting assessment and the RBMI (Risk Based Mechanical Integrity) program.  The calculated volume for this process unit changed from 48,413 lbs. to 117,300 lbs.

_prev_prog_3.Description:
Tank Farm
Basic Process Description
The tank farm is not really a process but is used for the storage of crude oil, finished products that will either be sold as a finished product or blended with other stocks, and products that will be used as stocks for other refinery processes.  Tanks range in size from 310,000 barrels (42 gal.) to less than a 1,000 barrels.

Inspections:
Tanks are inspected on a scheduled basis using inspection intervals established by regulatory, industry standards (API,NBIC,ASME),and recognized best practices. Inspection intervals, tracking and completion of Inspections are handled by the refinery MI (Mechanical Integrity)program/group.                                                                                                                                                                                                                          
Ongoing management 
The ongoing management of refinery process hazards requires the regular implementation of many PSM/RMP prevention elements.  Changes regularly occur in refinery processes, which require modifications to the process safety information, implementation of the management of change procedure, and require a pre-startup safety review.  Incident Reports are written regularly to document and investigate incidents that resulted in; property damage, environmental contamination, vehicle accidents, and injuries including first aid or incidents that may have resulted in something occurring (such as process upsets).  Incident Reports are considered a key component in our overall prevention program as we focus on learning from small incidents before they become significant.

As part of this 2009 update, Tesoro recalculated process volumes for each unit using detailed engineering calculations. This was done because we also used these detailed quantities in a facility siting assessment and the RBMI (Risk Based Mechanical Integrity)program.  The calculated volume for the Tank Farm changed from 971,015,940 lbs. to 163,203,168 lbs.

_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Detailed Engineering calculations of Toxics and Flammables in unit
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Diesel Desulfurization Unit
Basic process description: 
The Diesel Desulfurization Unit (DDU) uses a hydrotreating process to remove sulfur from the No. 2 Diesel (DF2) and and Arctic Diesel (DFA) produced in the Crude Unit.To do this,the hydrotreating process converts the sulfur in the diesel to hydrogen sulfide (H2S) that is stripped out of the diesel products in the Fractionation section of the unit.
The DDU produces diesel products with a sulfur content below 15 ppm. At this sulfur level, the products meet the Environmental Protection Agency's Ultra Low Sulfur Diesel (ULSD) specification. The two ULSD products made in the DDU are a summer-grade diesel called No. 2-D S15 and a winter-grade diesel called No. 1-D S15. The DDU also produces a sour naphtha product that is piped to the Hydrocracker to be stabilized and a sour offgas that is sweetened in the Amine Unit before being used as fuel gas in the refinery.


Inspections
All process units (including the DDU) were involved in a major plant turnaround in April/May 2009.  This is a time in which normally operating processes are shut down for maintenance and inspections (except the tank farm).  Many process vessels were inspected during a three-week period the date of May 1st was used as the date of last inspection 

Ongoing management 
The ongoing management of refinery process hazards requires the regular implementation of many PSM/RMP prevention elements.  Changes regularly occur in refinery processes, which require modifications to the process safety information, implementation of the management of change procedure, and require a pre-startup safety review.  Incident Reports are written regularly to document and investigate incidents that resulted in; property damage, environmental contamination, vehicle accidents, and injuries including first aid or incidents that may have resulted in something occurring (such as process upsets).  Incident Reports are considered a key component in our overall prevention program as we focus on learning from small incidents before they become significant.

 In 2007, Tesoro installed the Distillate Desulfurization Unit at the plant. Although this process before it went on line was calculated by the unit design company and a consultant, to not hold enough toxic or flammable material to meet the definition of an RMP covered process. New detailed engineering calculations now show that it has 17,049 lbs. of flammables, making it an RMP covered process.

_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: T-401 Stabilizer Tower, T-402 Fractionator Tower, V-404 Stabilizer Receiver
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Hydrocracker
Basic Process Description
The Hydrocracker takes gas oil, a low value fuel oil produced in the Crude and Vacuum Units, mixes it with hydrogen under high pressure (1500 psig) and temperature.  And sends it through a catalytic reactor that converts it into jet fuel, naphtha, gasoline, LPG, and fuel gas.  The naphtha, also called heavy hydrocrackate or HHC, is sent to the Reformer Unit for further processing.  The LPG and fuel gases contain high concentrations of hydrogen sulfide.  They are sent to the Amine Unit for hydrogen sulfide removal.

Inspections
All process units (including the Hydrocracker) were involved in a major plant turnaround in April/May 2009.  This is a time in which normally operating processes are shut down for maintenance and inspections (except the tank farm).  Many process vessels were inspected during a three-week period the date of May 1st was used as the date of last inspection 

Ongoing management 
The ongoing management of refinery process hazards requires the regular implementation of many PSM/RMP prevention elements.  Changes regularly occur in refinery processes, which require modifications to the process safety information, implementation of the management of change procedure, and require a pre-startup safety review.  Incident Reports are written regularly to document and investigate incidents that resulted in; property damage, environmental contamination, vehicle accidents, and injuries including first aid or incidents that may have resulted in something occurring (such as process upsets).  Incident Reports are considered a key component in our overall prevention program as we focus on learning from small incidents before they become significant.

As part of this 2009 update, Tesoro recalculated process volumes for each unit using detailed engineering calculations. This was done because we also used these detailed quantities in a facility siting assessment and the RBMI (Risk Based Mechanical Integrity) program.  The calculated volume for this process unit changed from 253,019 lbs. to 326,000 lbs.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
TESORO ALASKA COMPANY KENAI REFINERY
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

TESORO ALASKA COMPANY KENAI REFINERY
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
FIVE-YEAR UPDATE A? June 2009


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

The Tesoro Alaska Company (Tesoro) Kenai refinery has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes.  Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.


DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Kenai refinery, located in Nikiski, Alaska, operates a variety of processes to produce petroleum products (e.g., diesel, jet fuel, pentane, propane,and butane from raw crude oil.  The refinery uses or produces several regulated flammables, such as pentane, propane, butane, ethane and methane.

As part of this 2009 update, Tesoro recalculated process volumes for each unit using detailed engineering calculations. This was done because we also used these detailed quantities in a facility siting assessment and the RBMI (Risk Based Mechanical Integrity) program. The revised estimate of flammable volumes in the Vacuum Unit dropped from 298,000 pounds to 3,000 pounds, removing it from the list of covered processes.
     

HAZARD ASSESSMENT

The original hazard assessment using both a worst-case scenario and an alternative scenario for the Tesoro refinery was reviewed to ensure all modeling inputs, including process volumes and composition, are still valid. The offsite consequence analysis was updated with a new A?alternative release scenarioA? which replaced the previous scenenario and to reflect current population estimates. 


FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

At Tesoro we are proud of our safety performance.  The Kenai refinery has had an excellent record of accident prevention since the start of our operation in 1969.  In fact, we have never experienced an incident that impacted people or property outside of the refinery since 1969.  One reason for our success at preventing accidents is that we investigate even minor incidents promptly and thoroughly to determine ways to prevent similar incidents from occurring.  Thus, we can eliminate many incidents before they become problems.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS

The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at the Kenai refinery. This program includes the required elements of our Process Safety Management program.

Employee Participation
The Kenai refinery encourages employees to participate in all facets of safety management and accident prevention.  Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team.  Employees have access to all information created as part of the Refinery Safety Program.  Regularly held safety meetings in each department are one way in which employee's are able to participate in the review and development of programs and work practices. Any employee can enter(write)Incident Reports or write a Safety Suggestion if they have concerns over personnel or process safety. Tesoro also started a (volunteer) behavior based safety program called the A?EaglesA? which audits regularly for behavioral based safety issues.  Other specific ways that employees can be involved in the Refinery Safety Program are documented in an employee participation plan that is maintained at the refinery.

Process Safety Information
The Kenai refinery keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes.  The documents address chemical properties and a

ssociated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information.  Specific departments within the refinery are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date process safety information. 

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDS).  This information is supplemented by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns and any known hazards associated with the inadvertent mixing of chemicals.  The refinery has developed procedures for operating the processes within safe limits for temperature, level, composition, etc.  The refinery ensures that the processes are maintained within these limits using process controls, monitoring instruments, trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems).

The refinery also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment.  This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc.  This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.

Process Hazard Analysis
The Kenai refinery has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards. 

The Kenai refinery primarily uses the hazard and operability (HAZOP) analysis technique to perform these evaluations. HAZOP analysis is recognized as one of the most sys

tematic and thorough hazard evaluation techniques.  The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise.  This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.

The PHA team findings are reviewed and resolved by local management. Implementation of mitigation options in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team.  This ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive immediate attention.  All approved mitigation options being implemented in response to PHA team findings are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.

To help ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate significantly from the original design safety features, the Kenai refinery periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results.  Periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating.  The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained.  Once again, the team findings are forwarded to management for consideration, and the final resolution of the findings is documented and retained.

Operating Procedures
The Kenai refinery maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as unit startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, normal shutdown, and initial startup of a new process.  These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  Procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate.  They are

4)    Understand what they should do in the event of an emergency;
(5)    Understand and follow site safety rules; and
(6)    Inform refinery personnel of any hazards that they find during their work.

This is accomplished by providing contractors with:
(1)    A process overview;
(2)    Information about safety and health hazards;
(3)    Emergency response plan requirements; and
(4)    Safe work practices prior to their beginning work.

Information is provided to contractors during the mandatory contractor orientation.  This orientation provides contractors with the general knowledge of the refinery operations, its hazards, work practices, and evacuation procedures for emergencies.

The Kenai refinery evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the selection of a contractor. Tesoro Corporate has its refineries using A?PICSA? (Pacific Industrial Contractor Screening), a third party consulting company who evaluates and monitors contractor qualifications and safety records. Contractors are to be approved by PICS before they enter the Refinery. Refinery personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations. The Eagles (behavioral based safety program) also do observations on contractors as well as have some trained observers in the Eagles program who are contractors. 

Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSR)
The Kenai refinery conducts a PSSR for any facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information.  The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service.  This review provides an additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all systems are operationally ready.  The PSSR team uses checklists to verify all aspects of readiness.  A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assu

repairs are made.

Safe Work Practices
The Kenai refinery has long-standing safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety.  Examples include:
(1)    Control of the entry/presence/exit of contract personnel with a 24 hr. security staff;
(2)    A lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance;
(3)    A procedure for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened;
(4)    A permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities (i.e., hot work); and
(5)    A permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into confined spaces.
These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

Management of Change
The Kenai refinery has a comprehensive system to manage changes to processes.  This system requires that changes' to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating parameters), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to:
(1)    Ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards;
(2)    Verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change;
(3)    Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures are updated to incorporate these changes; and
(4)    Operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training on the change.

Incident Investigation
The Kenai refinery promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably had the potential to have resulted in, a fire, explosion, or toxic gas release, that could have caused major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury.  The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the inci

dent or a similar incident.  The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to refinery management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings.  Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years so that the reports can be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations.

Compliance Audits
To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, the Kenai refinery periodically conducts an audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented.  Compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years by a Corporate approved / appointed audit team, or a third party consulting firm mixed with Tesoro personnel from across the Corporation.  The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to refinery management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.



CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The processes at the Kenai refinery have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation.  The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all EPA RMP-covered processes at the Kenai refinery.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures or human errors. 

In addition to the accident prevention program activities, the Kenai refinery has safety features on many units to help contain and control a release, quick

elta V boiler control system in the CoGen with Foxboro I/A; and
(7)  Change from high pressure anhydrous ammonia to aqueous ammonia.
